image.altText: A elderly man, in his 80s, stony-faced and serious, looks directly at the camera. the photo is black and white.

props.synopsis: Gerald Murnane rarely leaves his tiny Victorian town, but bookies are giving him high odds to win this year's Nobel Prize for Literature.

title.children: This literary giant lives a humble life in western Victoria. On Thursday, the world spotlight could be on him

image.altText: A ute with a toolbox drives down a mainstreet surrounded by businesses.

props.synopsis: The 19-year-old Mansfield apprentice was inside the toolbox for more than 20 minutes while his director drove between jobs. The apprentice recorded a video commenting on the heat and his discomfort.

title.children: Plumber fined $20,000 after putting young apprentice in ute toolbox

image.altText: Milk bottles in a supermarket fridge with a red 'Lower Shelf Price' sign in the window

props.synopsis: Coles and Woolworths say they’re passing milk price reductions on to shoppers. But what do shelf price cuts mean for the farmers who produce the milk?

title.children: Supermarkets drop milk price to lowest since 2010 as farmers fear return of 'milk wars'

image.altText: Marley Wright-Martin wears a grey t-shirt and smiles at the camera in front of some bushes.

props.synopsis: Marley Wright-Martin, 27, was being held in solitary confinement at Port Phillip Prison when he died in September. His family has given permission for his name and image to be used.

title.children: 'We should all be outraged': Family of Aboriginal man who died in custody calls for answers

image.altText: A shopping trolley full of essentials items like fruit, water, and eggs.

props.synopsis: ABS figures show only 6.5 per cent of the population meets the daily requirement of five servings of vegetables and the effects are being felt across the economy.

title.children: Australians are not eating enough vegetables and it's not just our health that is suffering

image.altText: A man in a suit

props.synopsis: White supremacist Jacob Hersant has become the first person found guilty of breaking a Victorian law that bans performing the Nazi salute in public.

title.children: Far-right extremist who challenged validity of Nazi salute ban becomes first Victorian to be found guilty of new offence

image.altText: Jesse Wardlaw of the Saints reacts after kicking a goal, puffing out her chest and yelling

props.synopsis: Coach Nick Dal Santo is not daring to dream of the AFLW finals after St Kilda snapped a three-game losing streak with a 34-point win over GWS.

title.children: Saints snap losing streak but refuse to think about finals

image.altText: Man sitting at board room table speaking to politicians

props.synopsis: The delivery of two new Spirit of Tasmania vessels has faced significant scrutiny over its repeated delays and cost blowouts. The former chair of the ferry operator has now taken aim at the government over its "appalling" support

title.children: Spirit of Tasmania saga escalates with claims of safety risks, 'appalling' support and strained relationships

image.altText: passersby walk by a tent made of an old sign on a waterfront promenade

props.synopsis: About 1.2 million people have been forced from their homes by Israel's bombardment and invasion, the Lebanese government says. They fill the public spaces around Beirut – footpaths, squares, churchyards and schools.

title.children: Beirut's famous waterfront taken over by people fleeing Israeli air strikes

image.altText: A man holding a small child speaks into a microphone.

props.synopsis: Sydney sports writer Bilal Nassour became stuck on a work trip to Beirut and witnessed the Israeli air strike which killed Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah. Now back in Australia, he is anxious for those left behind.

title.children: 'The scariest ride': Australians who fled Lebanon describe desperate escape and terrifying flight home

image.altText: Anthony Albanese confused in QT

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese makes a formal apology for an off-colour taunt in the chamber yesterday, when he asked a heckling MP if they had Tourette's. Follow live.

title.children: Albanese apologises for off-colour Tourette's taunt during heat of Question Time

image.altText: Imran Khan sits in a dark room in front of a Pakistan flag talking to someone out of picture

props.synopsis: Former Pakistani prime minister Imran Khan is charged with the attempted murder of a police officer critically injured during protests in Islamabad.

title.children: Imran Khan charged with attempted murder of Pakistani police officer

image.altText: Illustration of autonomous self-driving cars.

props.synopsis: A Choice investigation has found most of Australia's popular car brands collect and share "driver data", ranging from braking patterns to video footage and voice recognition information.

title.children: Cars are data-harvesting machines. These brands share your personal information

image.altText: A family of four embrace in outback Australia

props.synopsis: Outback tourism operators are feeling the squeeze as soaring costs and increasing global competition cut into visitor numbers.

title.children: 'Why are we waiting for retirement?': This family sold their home to experience outback Australia

image.altText: A group of Italian internees in Australia, WWII

props.synopsis: The impulsive fear and punishment of innocent people on the grounds of their appearance or garments or last name is a phenomenon you'd hope had disappeared — but it's a mistake we keep making.

title.children: Generations of foreign-born Australians have been punished for their heritage. It's a mistake we keep making

image.altText: Sheila Raymond and family members

props.synopsis: Sheila Thurlow's family is calling for an inquest into her death at a Brisbane hospital after she was injected with 1,000 times the intended dose of morphine.

title.children: Nurse 'Googled' hospital procedure night before woman was given 1,000 times the intended level of morphine

image.altText: Donald Trump stands at a podium, holds his hands outstretched and smiles.

props.synopsis: Australia would be among the countries that would suffer most from what Trump is proposing, after the US and China.

title.children: From mass deportations to huge tariff hikes, here's what Trump's economic program would do to the US and Australia

image.altText: A hand holds two Australian passports in Central Park, New York.

props.synopsis: A glitch in Indonesia's e-visa system is inadvertently exposing sensitive traveller information to strangers with at least three Australians able to see passport details of other people.

title.children: 'We are aware of this problem': Australian tourists say private details exposed at Bali Airport

image.altText: Partly smiling older woman with shaggy brown hair cut short, wears black and white striped tee and a necklace around her neck

props.synopsis: With its picturesque canals and waterfront homes, the Victorian holiday haven of Paynesville appears immune to the poverty that is quietly gripping the nation. But Foodbank Victoria says the reality is much harsher than it looks.

title.children: Hunger relief charity struggles as food insecurity becomes a 'disaster behind closed doors'

image.altText: Three school students look at phone

props.synopsis: As national leaders grapple with ways to best protect young minds from the potentially harmful effects of social media, students are already talking through some of the issues, and opening up about how taking time out from TikTok and other platforms has helped them live offline.

title.children: Students open up on TikTok detox amid ban talk, as platform reveals it booted a million underage accounts

image.altText: Close up picture of a woman

props.synopsis: At just 23, Charen has lived on the streets, navigated addiction and been in and out of prison and rehab. She's now participating in a six-month program that's providing a successful alternative to prison for many.

title.children: In this custody 'camp', incarcerated women wear their own clothes and get tailored rehabilitation

image.altText: Katy Gallagher portrait

props.synopsis: The Flinders University study found the first year of the entitlement was a success but recommended greater education about the scheme for both employers and employees.

title.children: Paid domestic violence leave underutilised in first year

image.altText: A photo of a man with a beard wearing a white and red shirt.

props.synopsis: Paniora Nukunuku was confused when he walked into his local Woolworths and saw a new red label with the words "low prices" on his regular can of corned beef — the price hadn't gone down, it had increased.

title.children: Hundreds of consumers took matters into their own hands to keep the big supermarkets accountable

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: New construction data is due today, so has the market turned the corner? Plus, the broadening Middle East conflict continues to roil markets. See how the day unfolds on the markets blog.

title.children: New construction data expected as Middle East conflict roils markets

image.altText: A woman gestures toward the camera

props.synopsis: Dramatic developments at Fiji's Independent Commission Against Corruption reveal broader teething problems with the country's transition from dictatorship to democracy.

title.children: Fiji's anti-corruption chief allegedly went drinking and night-swimming with a judge. It's not the strangest thing about this story

image.altText: A graphic shows a ballot box with Olympics 2032 written on it.

props.synopsis: There's a predictable pattern an Olympics host city goes through in the lead-up to holding the biggest sporting event on earth. First there's excitement, then there's disillusionment — that's arguably where Brisbane is now.

title.children: 'Let's dump the Olympics': Games host cities follow a predictable pattern, starting with excitement. Brisbane is at 'disillusionment'

image.altText: Cyber hacking

props.synopsis: Australian businesses who make ransomware payments to hackers could be forced to report their actions to authorities under new cybersecurity laws being introduced to parliament on Wednesday.

title.children: Businesses encouraged to share private data with government agencies, under new cyber laws to fight ransomware threat

image.altText: Australia's Megan Schutt in the delivery stride of a bowl during a world cup match

props.synopsis: A disciplined bowling performance has earned Australia a second successive victory in the Women's T20 World Cup, a 60-run win over New Zealand.

title.children: Schutt claims World Cup record as Australia moves closer to semifinal berth

image.altText: Three images of Beabadoobee, Charli XCX and Clairo performing onstage

props.synopsis: It's here, it's happening, are you hanging onto something stable? Your Laneway Festival line-up has arrived.

title.children: Charli XCX, Clairo and Beabadoobee lead Laneway Festival 2025 line-up

image.altText: Two police officers in formal attire lead an older man down a flight of stairs outside a suburban home.

props.synopsis: NSW Police say the woman became seriously ill after the man allegedly slipped insecticide into tea he was preparing for his wife last month.

title.children: Man charged with poisoning offences after allegedly slipping insecticide into wife's tea

image.altText: Man in blue shirt smiling at a shorter woman in a pink shirt.

props.synopsis: There was never any question Michael Pitt was going to work on the land. But a mustering accident triggered a long-held desire to become a doctor, and now he and his nurse wife Katie use their agricultural backgrounds to connect with rural patients.

title.children: After a bull charged at him, this grazier retrained to become a doctor

image.altText: An image of cows eating a feed in a row

props.synopsis: Dairy Australia says about 20 per cent of the milk produced in Australia now comes from intensive or housed systems and expects it could reach 40 per cent within the next 20 years.

title.children: More of Australia's milk will soon be coming from a cow that doesn't eat grass

image.altText: A man pointing at a screen. There are students behind him.

props.synopsis: Swinburne University's Matthew Bailes has been recognised for his role in discovering fast radio bursts, which are now used by scientists to learn about the Universe.

title.children: Astrophysicist wins 2024 PM's Prize for Science for fast radio burst discovery

image.altText: A navy blue sign with the words Nobel Prize in Physics 2024.

props.synopsis: The scientists won the award for their discoveries and inventions that enable machine learning within artificial neural networks.

title.children: Scientists win Nobel Prize in Physics for developing methods that are 'the foundation' of AI

image.altText: A performer shines a torch towards another performer dressed as a turtle.

props.synopsis: Green sea turtles in the Torres Strait are under threat from climate change. These Torres Strait artists are using Bangarra Dance Theatre's first show for kids to tell their story to people all over the country.

title.children: How do you talk to kids about the threat climate change poses to their home? Through the power of dance
